required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pelvic Floor Exercise Before Surgery in Women With Pelvic Organ Prolapse
clinical_study.official_title: Pelvic Floor Exercise Before Surgery in Women With Pelvic Organ Prolapse

collaborator.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock:
The lifetime risk for a woman to undergo surgery for either vaginal prolapse or urinary incontinence is high. There are many different surgical techniques for treatment of prolapse, but there is a lack of knowledge about factors that contribute to objective result and patient satisfaction after surgery.
The aim of the study is to investigate factors that could be related to patient satisfaction and objective result such as pelvic floor muscle contractility/strength and muscle injury, objective measures of prolapse and women's symptoms. This study will investigate whether systematic pelvic floor exercise and life style advise before surgery can improve outcomes after surgery for either vaginal prolapse. Another aim is to determine an ultrasound scale for measure of pelvic floor muscle contraction.

primary_outcome.measure: Pelvic floor muscle strength assessed by palpation
primary_outcome.description: Muscle strength is evaluated using 6 point modified Oxford Scale (MOS) range 0-5.

primary_outcome.measure: Pelvic floor muscle strength assessed by ultrasound
primary_outcome.description: Changes in pelvic floor muscle at rest and during pelvic floor contraction, measured in mm and calculated proportional change
Symptoms of pelvic floor disorders assessed by validated questionnaire (PDFI-20)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pelvic floor muscle strength assessed by perineometry
secondary_outcome.description: measuring the pressure with vaginal manometry in cm H2O during pelvic floor contraction

secondary_outcome.measure: Pelvic floor muscle strength assessed by electromyography
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by vaginal surface electrode during pelvic floor contraction, measured in mV

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of anatomical pelvic organ prolapse
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment with the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) System

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of anatomical sphincter ani defect
secondary_outcome.description: Anatomical sphincter ani defect assessed by transperineal ultrasound

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of levator ani muscle trauma
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by transperineal ultrasound on contraction and Valsalva

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of pelvic organ mobility as a measure of pelvic organ function/dysfunction
secondary_outcome.description: Movement of the pelvic organs during Valsalva and contraction

secondary_outcome.measure: Imaging of synthetic implants assessed by ultrasound
secondary_outcome.description: Registration of implants after pelvic floor surgery and their relations to anatomical structures in mm.
Symptoms of pelvic floor disorders assessed by validated questionnaire (PFIQ-7)
Symptoms of pelvic floor disorders assessed by visual analogue scale (VAS 1-10)

arm_group.description: pelvic floor exercises individually and in groups

intervention.description: In preparation for surgery, patients receive individual information by a physiotherapist on pelvic floor anatomy and correct pelvic floor contraction. Patients are told to do the following pelvic floor exercises 3 times a day: 8-12 maximal contractions, hold contractions during 10 seconds, and 3 fast contractions after each long contraction. In addition exercise in groups with skilled physical therapists once a week during 12 weeks.
patients wait as usual until surgery without special treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- referred to surgery for urogenital prolapse
- informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- not able to communicate in Norwegian or English
- not able or willing to sign informed consent

overall_official.affiliation: St Olavs Hospital University Hospital Trondheim

reference.citation: Nyhus MØ, Oversand SH, Salvesen Ø, Salvesen KÅ, Mathew S, Volløyhaug I. Ultrasound assessment of pelvic floor muscle contraction: reliability and development of an ultrasound-based contraction scale. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2020 Jan;55(1):125-131. doi: 10.1002/uog.20382. Epub 2019 Dec 13.

results_reference.citation: Nyhus MØ, Mathew S, Salvesen Ø, Salvesen KÅ, Stafne S, Volløyhaug I. Effect of preoperative pelvic floor muscle training on pelvic floor muscle contraction and symptomatic and anatomical pelvic organ prolapse after surgery: randomized controlled trial. Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol. 2020 Jul;56(1):28-36. doi: 10.1002/uog.22007. Epub 2020 Jun 9.
